journeys.title: Beginning the Journey
journeys.body: The Central Mediterranean Route is long and dangerous, so most migrants rely on smugglers throughout their journey to navigate across borders or treacherous environments.

entourages.body: Migrants encounter several risks along their journey. 20 percent of migrants are concerned about their personal safety. 14% experience shelter-related problems. Additionally, 18% of migrants are affected food insecurity.
Many migrants hire smugglers to help along the journey. The decisions they make in regards to smuggling impact their levels of vulnerability.
In organized smuggling, the whole journey is organized and migrants are accompanied for most of the journey
In step-by-step smuggling, migrants mostly travel on their own and only use a smuggler for certain segments of the journey, like crossing a border or the desert.

Migrants heading to Libya through the Central Mediterranean route typically originate from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), and carry passports which allow them to pass through most country borders along the way without a visa.

journeys.title: Passing through Agadez
journeys.body: Cities, such as Agadez, serve as transitory destinations along the Central Mediterranean route. Some migrants stop here to find smugglers, while others stop for extended periods of time to find work to fund the next part of their journey.

entourages.body: Most migrants are continuously on the move. Only 10 percent of migrants stop in a place for longer than 1 month before reaching Libya.
Migrants’ cannot use their ECOWAS passports at the Libya border, so they need to locate smugglers in Agadez to help them cross into Libya.
In Agadez, migrants must remain hidden in crowded small houses with many other migrants in the outskirts of the city, as they await smuggler transport to Libya.

journeys.title: Crossing the Sahara Desert
journeys.body: Smugglers drive migrants in pick-up trucks for 3 days across the Sahara Desert. This informal route is the most dangerous part of the journey, where migrants risk violence, extortion, nutrition deficiencies, and vehicle accidents.

entourages.body: Pickup trucks with ~25 passengers on the back (migrants from West Africa and short-time laborers from Niger). Migrants wrap their heads in turbans for sun protection and brace themselves with stick to keep from falling out of the truck.
Rest station along the way. The 2015 Law 036 EU-Niger prohibits smuggling in Niger. This has led to smugglers using longer routes, which are more dangerous and expensive.

When trucks break down, passengers are forced to walk. This exposes migrants to extreme heat risk with little access to shelter or water. Average high temperatures in the Sahara Desert reach 38 degrees celsius.

Just as migrants are exposed to extreme heat during the day, the Sahara Desert can be a cold place at night, so migrants burn tires to keep warm. The Sahara Desert reach average low temperatures of -4 degrees celsius at night--posing another health risk for migrants.

Trucks heading back to Agadez with workers from Libya. Majority converts earnings into goods (furniture, clothes, appliances and other household items) to bring home because the Libyan dinar is unstable

Tombs sarked by jagged stones, an empty water jug are found along the way. Migrants report the highest number of deaths (28% of migrants reporting) along this part of the Central Mediterranean Route (4mi)

journeys.title: Entering Libya
journeys.body: When migrants enter Libya they face heightened risks including detention, risks to personal safety, and food insecurity.

entourages.body: In order to pass into Libya, smugglers often bribe security personnel, or skirt around border crossings and security checkpoints, such as the major Tumo border checkpoint in Southern Libya.

Since the fall of Gaddafi in 2011, ethnic militia groups have control over northern Niger and southern Libya–including the migrant smuggling economy and security checkpoints. These groups are constantly vying for control of the border areas--which means migrants must adapt to constantly changing smuggling dynamics
In Libya, many migrants face detention by the DCIM. In detention centers, migrants are often subject to harsh living conditions, physical violence, and death.
After crossing into Libya, smugglers place migrants in holding locations in border towns like Qatrun where they are often subject to extortion.

journeys.title: Passing through Sabha
journeys.body: Sabha is one of the first major cities migrants pass through after arriving in Libya. Most migrants use Sabha as a transit point, rather than a place to settle.

entourages.body: Migrants see Sabha as a transitory stop, rather than a place to settle. 10 percent of migrants residing in Sabha consider it to be their final destination.
Unrest in southern Libya poses particular danger to migrants in Sabha. The risks migrants in Sabha most commonly face are personal safety (35%), low income (33%), and violence/conflict (22%)

Migrants often change hands in or near Sabha from southern-Libyan ethnic groups to Arab smugglers. During this transition, smugglers may keep migrants in hidden compounds while they arrange for smugglers to take them to a coastal city, and some reportedly lure migrants into trafficking where they are sold as slaves.

Some migrants make a ‘voluntary return’ to their country of origin, are deported, or choose to leave Libya because of poor living conditions. As a result, migrants may be left stranded in the Sahara, and at urban transit stops on the route, or return to their country of origin with little access to resources

journeys.title: Reaching Tripoli
journeys.body: While Tripoli serves as a disembarkation point for migrants taking the sea route to Europe, it is also a place where many migrants choose to settle.

entourages.body: Tripoli serves more as a place of resettlement for migrants compared to Sabha. 31 percent of migrants in Tripoli consider it to be their final destination.

As a place of resettlement, economic conditions take greater importance in Tripoli. The risks migrants in Tripoli most commonly face are low income (66%), lack of employment (60%), and food insecurity (22%).

Employment increases the likelihood of vulnerability for migrants. Contributing to higher employment-related vulnerability are factors such as informal work contracts, and lack of access to digital banking services.

Departures from Libya: Some migrants attempt to make the sea crossing from Libya to Europe. This part of the journey can be very dangerous–and many migrants die at sea. Migrants intercepted by the Libyan coast guard are often sent to detention centers in Libya.

journeys.title: Current Conditions in Libya
journeys.body: Migrants in Libya experience a range of outcomes. Some leave the country by embarking to Europe or through deportation, while others may stay to work. Each pathway exposes migrants to a different set of risks.

narrativeTexts.title: Policy Recommendation 1
narrativeTexts.body: Since the main push factor for migrants to leave their countries of origin is economic wage differentials, WFP should focus efforts on building economic opportunities at the country of origin. Such efforts could include employment generation programmes in partnership with national governments, training opportunities in the technology sector, or engagement in rural food systems programmes.

narrativeTexts.title: Policy Recommendation 2
narrativeTexts.body: Many migrants send remittances through risky or costly informal channels--lacking formal bank accounts. Improving digital banking access for migrants residing in Libya will reduce their financial vulnerability.

narrativeTexts.title: Policy Recommendation 3
narrativeTexts.body: In locations where migrants settle or use as protracted transit sites, WFP and partners should address food insecurity and other humanitarian requirements through existing social protection systems, also considering the needs of the host population to avoid potential tensions.
